newsitem.title: UK: Euro oil swaps all head southwards, mogas big fall.
newsitem.headline: Euro oil swaps all head southwards, mogas big fall.

text.p: European oil swaps slipped on Monday playing catch-up to crude's late losses on Friday.
Brent crude CFDs dipped a few cents while gasoline lost $8 a tonne and naphtha shed $3 or so. Fuel was also lower by $1.
Brent CFD trade got off to a slow start with this week sliding to -53 cents against July Brent from -47 cents on Friday.
Next week was -44/45 cents compared with -37/38 cents. June 23-27 was pegged at -36 cents under July while June 30- July 4 was -29/30 cents under from -21 cents under. Nothing was heard done.
Gas oil crack spreads were steasdy with Q97 at $4.70 and Q198 at $4.65.
Gasoline dropped with physical eurograde barges trading at $188 a tonne AR and $189 fob ARA, about $7-8 below the lowest deal levels on Friday.
June swaps were pegged around $189 from $195 while July was put at $184 from $188. The spread has narrowed to $5 or so compared with times last week when it was up to $8 a tonne.
Better wet supplies and a closed arb to the U.S trapping product in northwest Europe contributed the bearish pressure on prompt gasoline numbers.
Naphtha swaps slipped $3 or so with June valued around $180 and July talked flat with August about $1-2 contangoed.
Heavy fuel lost $1 with June swaps talked around $84 on the bid side and July about 50 cents contangoed.
Dealers said activity had been sluggish in the morning, but was picking up. A low sulphur June swaps traded at $92.00, about $1 weaker than Friday's levels.
